data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Right now... your body is losing muscle. And you have ZERO idea it's happening.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Three to five percent. Every single year. After sixty.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: No pain. No warning. Just... quietly vanishing.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: And most people think — that's just getting older. That's NORMAL.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: But here's the thing... the World Health Organization disagrees.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Medical infographic showing WHO disease classification. Large blue WHO logo at top center. Below: bold white text SARCOPENIA with red border. Subtitle: Officially classified as a DISEASE — two thousand nineteen. Split comparison below: LEFT grey box NORMAL AGING with X mark, RIGHT green box PREVENTABLE CONDITION with upward arrow. Dark background, clean medical poster style, high contrast, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: A disease. Not normal aging — a DISEASE.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Which means it can be fought. Slowed down... even reversed, in many cases.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: But ONLY if you know what you're actually up against.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And here's what nobody tells you — there is ONE habit... something most people over sixty do every single day... that DOUBLES how fast you lose muscle.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: We're going to reveal exactly what it is. But not yet — first, you need to understand WHY this matters so much.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Hey everyone — I'm Dr. Michael Harris, cardiologist, thirty years in practice.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: And I'm Dr. Hiroshi Saito, preventive medicine specialist. Michael — let's get into it.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Alright. So most people hear 'muscle loss after sixty' and they think: I just need to exercise more, right?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That's the standard advice, yes. Walk more, stay active.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And I disagree with that STRONGLY. Because 'just walk more' is one of the most dangerous myths in medicine right now.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That's a bold claim, Michael. Walking IS beneficial — the research supports that clearly.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: For your HEART — absolutely. But for building muscle after sixty?
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Cause-effect comparison infographic. LEFT green box: walking shoe icon with heart symbol, label WALKING — HEART HEALTH: YES. CENTER: large red X divider. RIGHT grey box: muscle fiber icon fading, label MUSCLE AFTER 60: MINIMAL EFFECT. Bold arrow flow left to right. Dark background, green-to-red contrast, high contrast labels, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Hmm. I want to push back on that — but I'll hear your reasoning first.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Your muscles need a SPECIFIC type of stimulus to grow. Walking simply doesn't deliver that stimulus.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: What kind of stimulus are we talking about?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Resistance. Your muscles need to be CHALLENGED — pushed beyond their normal daily load.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: In Japan... we actually see this happen naturally. Farmers, fishermen — they carry heavy loads all day.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And THAT is exactly why they maintain real strength well into their seventies and eighties.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: So the problem isn't that Americans don't walk. It's that they don't LIFT anything.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: That's the core of it. But let me back up — because we need to understand what sarcopenia actually IS.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Sarcopenia — the word itself means 'flesh vanishing.' From the Greek.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And that is EXACTLY what happens. Your muscle fibers — the actual fibers — start dying off.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Process diagram showing sarcopenia progression. Three stages left to right: Stage 1 healthy red muscle fiber bundle labeled AGE FORTY: FULL STRENGTH. Stage 2 partially thinned orange fibers labeled AGE FIFTY: GRADUAL LOSS. Stage 3 visibly reduced grey fibers labeled AGE SIXTY PLUS: SARCOPENIA. Downward trend arrows connecting stages. Dark background, red-to-grey color progression, bold English labels, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Not all at once — slowly... over many years.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Right. And here's what makes it so dangerous — your BRAIN stops sending the rebuild signal as efficiently.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: The signal actually breaks down?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: It weakens. Your muscles become RESISTANT to the growth signal. We call this anabolic resistance.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Medical infographic comparing signal reception at two ages. LEFT panel: young healthy cell with bright green arrow labeled GROWTH SIGNAL entering smoothly, text AGE THIRTY: SIGNAL RECEIVED FULLY. RIGHT panel: aging cell with faded weakened arrow being partially blocked, text AGE SIXTY PLUS: ANABOLIC RESISTANCE. Central divider labeled WHAT CHANGES WITH AGE. Dark background, green-to-red color shift, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Like a lock... that gets stiffer with age.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Perfect. The key — which is protein — still exists. But the lock is STIFF.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: So you need MORE force to open it. More protein... more exercise?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Both — but in the RIGHT way. And that's exactly what we're covering today.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: But Michael... people are watching this RIGHT NOW thinking: this is just what happens when you get old. They've accepted it.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And that acceptance... is exactly what's costing them their independence.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Independence. That's the REAL stakes here, isn't it.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Think about it — what does muscle loss actually LOOK like in daily life?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Stairs become difficult. Carrying groceries feels heavier than it used to.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Opening a jar. Getting up from a chair without pushing off. Holding a grandchild.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: These are NOT 'aging' problems. These are MUSCLE problems.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And by the time people NOTICE... they've already lost twenty to forty percent of their strength.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Statistical bar chart showing strength loss over time. Three horizontal bars: TOP green bar at full width labeled AGE SIXTY: ONE HUNDRED PERCENT BASELINE. MIDDLE orange bar at eighty percent labeled AGE SIXTY-FIVE: TWENTY PERCENT LOST. BOTTOM red bar at sixty percent labeled AGE SEVENTY: FORTY PERCENT LOST. Bold red warning text below: MOST PEOPLE NOTICE HERE — TOO LATE. Dark background, green-to-red progression, high contrast, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That's when people start looking for solutions — but by then... recovery is MUCH harder.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Much harder. But NOT impossible. That's the key message here.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: In Japan... we don't think of strength as something you 'lose.' We think of it as something you actively MAINTAIN.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: That mindset difference is HUGE. Americans wait until something breaks. Japanese maintain before it does.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: It's like a garden. You don't wait for the plants to die — you water them every day.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: I love that. But let me give people a NUMBER they can hold onto — because data sticks.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Fair enough. Give us the number.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: After sixty — if you do NOTHING different — you lose three to five percent of muscle mass every single year.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Statistical line chart showing muscle loss trajectory. X-axis: AGE from forty to eighty. Two lines: GREEN line labeled WITH ACTIVE INTERVENTION showing gradual slow decline. RED line labeled DO NOTHING showing steep accelerating decline. Large 3-5% text centered with subtitle ANNUAL LOSS WITHOUT ACTION. Y-axis labeled MUSCLE MASS PERCENT. Dark background, high contrast green versus red, bold labels, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: And with the RIGHT approach — that number changes DRAMATICALLY.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Some studies show active intervention can cut that loss by HALF... or even more.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Half. That's the difference between needing help getting dressed... and carrying your grandchildren.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Now — let's talk about WHERE this process starts. Because it does NOT start at sixty.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: When does it actually begin?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: The decline begins around FORTY. Slowly at first... almost unnoticeable.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Timeline infographic showing muscle loss onset. Horizontal timeline from age thirty to eighty. Green marker at thirty labeled PEAK MUSCLE MASS. Yellow warning triangle at forty labeled DECLINE BEGINS — SILENT. Orange marker at fifty labeled ONE TO TWO PERCENT PER YEAR. Red marker at sixty labeled THREE TO FIVE PERCENT — SARCOPENIA ZONE. Bold white text above: IT STARTS TWENTY YEARS EARLIER THAN YOU THINK. Dark background, color progression green-to-red, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: So by the time someone turns sixty... they've ALREADY been losing muscle for twenty years.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Which is why PREVENTION matters more than treatment at this stage.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: This is where I disagree with how American medicine approaches this — they wait for diagnosis.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And you're right — that is a serious problem in our system.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: In Japan... men and women start monitoring grip strength in their FORTIES. It's completely routine.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Grip strength — that's actually one of the BEST early predictors of overall muscle health.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: If your grip is weakening... your whole body is weakening. It's a window into everything.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: So here's what I want you to do RIGHT NOW — grab something near you. Squeeze it. Hard. Remember how that feels.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Because in six months... if you do nothing different... that squeeze WILL be weaker.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: But if you follow what we cover today — it won't be. It'll be STRONGER.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That's the promise we're making today. Not magic — just the right information, applied correctly.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And we're starting with the BIGGEST mistake most people make — and it has nothing to do with exercise.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Protein. And NOT the way you've been thinking about it.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p1

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Alright — let's talk about protein. Because everyone over sixty has been told: eat MORE protein, right?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That's the standard advice everywhere, yes.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And here's the problem — that advice is INCOMPLETE. And incomplete advice... can actually be WORSE than no advice at all.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: How so? Protein IS essential for muscle repair. The science is clear on that.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: It is. But after sixty, your body processes protein COMPLETELY differently.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Medical comparison infographic showing protein processing at two ages. LEFT panel labeled AGE THIRTY with protein molecule icon entering muscle cell smoothly, green checkmark, text EFFICIENT ABSORPTION — FULL SIGNAL. RIGHT panel labeled AGE SIXTY PLUS with same protein molecule partially blocked at cell entrance, yellow warning sign, text ANABOLIC RESISTANCE — REDUCED ABSORPTION. Central divider arrow labeled THE RULES CHANGE. Dark background, green-to-yellow contrast, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: The anabolic resistance we talked about earlier.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Exactly. So just eating MORE protein... doesn't actually solve the problem. It's not about the AMOUNT.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Then what IS it about?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: TIMING. When you eat your protein matters MORE than how much you eat.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That's a SIGNIFICANT claim, Michael. Most nutrition guidelines — even Japanese ones — focus on total daily intake.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And for people over sixty... those guidelines need to be updated.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: I'm skeptical. Show me WHY timing beats amount.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Here's why — your muscles can only USE so much protein at once. There's a hard ceiling.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Statistical infographic showing per-meal protein absorption limit. Large bold 35g number centered in white text with orange glow. Below: horizontal absorption scale showing GREEN zone ZERO TO THIRTY-FIVE GRAMS: MUSCLE USES ALL OF IT with full arrow, then RED zone ABOVE THIRTY-FIVE GRAMS: EXCESS — NOT USED FOR MUSCLE with overflow arrow pointing down to waste. Small meal icons at bottom: chicken breast, two eggs, fish fillet, Greek yogurt — each with gram labels. Dark background, green-to-red contrast, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Thirty-five grams... that's not a huge amount. A chicken breast, maybe two eggs.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Right. So if someone eats sixty grams at dinner and ten at breakfast — they're WASTING the difference.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: The muscle literally cannot absorb it all at once.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And THIS is where the real mistake happens — most Americans front-load nothing and back-load EVERYTHING.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Coffee for breakfast... massive dinner. Yes — that's extremely common in America.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: So your muscles go TWELVE... sometimes SIXTEEN hours without any protein signal at all.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: And remember — they're already RESISTANT to that signal after sixty. That's a dangerous combination.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: It's like starving a plant for a week... then drowning it with water on Sunday.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Cause-effect chain infographic showing skipped morning protein damage. LEFT: clock icon showing SIX AM — COFFEE ONLY with red X, label ZERO PROTEIN SIGNAL. CENTER: muscle fiber icon visibly shrinking with arrow labeled TWELVE TO SIXTEEN HOURS WITHOUT FUEL. RIGHT: large dinner plate showing SIXTY GRAMS PROTEIN with label TOO LATE — MUSCLE CANNOT ABSORB IT ALL. Left to right flow. Dark background, red warning theme, bold labels, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: In Japan... we eat three meals. Every single meal has protein — fish, tofu, eggs. It's built into the culture.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And THAT is a huge reason why Japanese populations show significantly lower sarcopenia rates.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: So the real fix... isn't eating MORE protein. It's spreading it OUT across the day.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Twenty-five to thirty-five grams... three times a day. Breakfast, lunch, dinner — EVERY meal.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Daily protein protocol timeline infographic. Three color-coded horizontal blocks: TOP yellow block with sun icon — BREAKFAST: TWENTY-FIVE TO THIRTY-FIVE GRAMS with egg and fish icons. MIDDLE orange block with clock icon — LUNCH: TWENTY-FIVE TO THIRTY-FIVE GRAMS with chicken and tofu icons. BOTTOM blue block with moon icon — DINNER: TWENTY-FIVE TO THIRTY-FIVE GRAMS with salmon and Greek yogurt icons. Bold white text at bottom: DAILY TARGET: SEVENTY-FIVE TO ONE HUNDRED FIVE GRAMS — SPREAD EVENLY. Dark background, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: And it doesn't have to be expensive — eggs, fish, chicken, Greek yogurt, tofu.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Affordable... accessible... and EFFECTIVE. That's the combination.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: But Michael — is protein timing REALLY more important than total amount?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: For people over sixty? Yes. Without question. The research from the University of Texas confirmed this directly.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: I actually read that study... and the results WERE striking. Older adults who distributed protein evenly retained significantly more muscle.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: So we ARE on the same page here, Hiroshi.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: We are — but I want to add one important thing. Protein QUALITY also matters. Not just quantity and timing.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Absolutely. Leucine content specifically. Animal proteins and certain plant proteins trigger muscle synthesis much better.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Leucine is the key amino acid that actually unlocks that 'stiff lock' we talked about earlier.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Good. So the protein message is clear: distribute it, prioritize leucine-rich sources, hit that twenty-five to thirty-five gram window.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Now... protein alone won't save your muscles. We need the OTHER half of this equation.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Exercise. But NOT the kind most people think.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: You said earlier — walking isn't enough. So what IS enough?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Resistance training. And before anyone panics — we are NOT talking about bodybuilding.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Good — because the WORDS 'resistance training' scare most people over sixty.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: They shouldn't. Resistance training is simply: making your muscles work against a force.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That includes things people already DO — carrying groceries, climbing stairs, lifting grandchildren.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Exactly. But to actually REVERSE sarcopenia... you need to be more intentional about it.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Split comparison infographic — cardio versus resistance for muscle health. LEFT panel labeled CARDIO: Walking, Swimming with heart icon in green showing HEART HEALTH: EXCELLENT and muscle fiber icon in grey showing MUSCLE AFTER 60: MINIMAL EFFECT. RIGHT panel labeled RESISTANCE: Lifting, Bands, Bodyweight with muscle icon in bold red showing MUSCLE GROWTH: YES and smaller heart icon in green showing HEART: ALSO BENEFITS. Bold center text: FOR MUSCLE AFTER SIXTY — RESISTANCE WINS. Dark background, green-grey versus red-green contrast, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: How often does someone actually need to do this?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Minimum two to three times per week. NOT every day — your muscles need recovery time between sessions.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Recovery is where the actual growth happens.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Right. The exercise BREAKS the muscle down slightly. Recovery is when it rebuilds — STRONGER than before.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Like forging steel — you heat it, hammer it... then let it cool. The cooling makes it strong.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And here's the GOOD news — you absolutely do not need a gym for this.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: What can someone do at home? Give us specifics.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Squats — even partial ones using a chair for support. Wall push-ups. Resistance bands... they cost fifteen dollars. Step-ups on a stair.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: These are all FUNCTIONAL movements — they translate directly to real life.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: That's the KEY. We're not training for looks — we're training for FUNCTION. Can you get up from a chair? Can you carry things?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: In Japan... we have a concept. 'Functional fitness.' It's not about lifting heavy in a gym.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Tell me more about that.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: My uncle Kenji — he's eighty-five. He cycles to the market every morning. Carries his own groceries. Tends his garden.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: He's doing resistance training... without ever calling it that.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Exactly. The soil bags, the digging, the bending — his muscles are constantly being challenged.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And at eighty-five... he has functional strength that most sixty-year-olds in America have already lost.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Movement woven into daily life — that's the Japanese approach. Not separate 'workout time.'
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: I like that philosophy. But for most Americans — we need structure, at least at the start.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Weekly resistance training protocol infographic. Three green boxes in a row labeled MONDAY, WEDNESDAY, FRIDAY. Each box contains: muscle group icons rotating through legs, upper body, full body. Exercise icons: chair squat, wall push-up, resistance band curl. Time label FIFTEEN TO TWENTY MINUTES below each. Grey boxes for rest days: TUESDAY, THURSDAY, SATURDAY, SUNDAY. Bold text at bottom: TWO TO THREE DAYS PER WEEK IS ALL YOU NEED. Dark background, green exercise days versus grey rest days, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Three days a week — that's genuinely manageable for anyone.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And the beautiful thing — even fifteen minutes of focused resistance work is enough to trigger muscle protein synthesis.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: So protein timing AND resistance exercise — those are the two main pillars.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Those are the two pillars. But Hiroshi — we promised people something at the beginning.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: The one habit that DOUBLES muscle loss speed.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Right. And we need to talk about it NOW — because it's not just one thing. It's actually THREE habits most people don't realize they're doing.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Three habits that are actively working AGAINST you — even if you're eating protein and exercising.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: This is where it gets uncomfortable — because I'm going to admit... I was guilty of two of them for YEARS.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Good. Because honesty is what makes people actually change.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p2

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Alright. The three habits that are SECRETLY accelerating your muscle loss. And number one — this one surprises almost everyone.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Let's hear it.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Chronic sitting. Not occasional sitting — CHRONIC. More than six hours a day... unbroken.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: But people DO move sometimes — they're not sitting ALL day long.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: That's the myth. Research shows — it's the UNBROKEN stretches that destroy muscle. Even if you exercised that morning.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Cause-effect chain infographic showing chronic sitting damage to muscle. LEFT: seated person icon with clock showing SIX PLUS HOURS and label CHRONIC SITTING. CENTER: red arrow labeled MUSCLE INACTIVITY SIGNAL pointing to muscle fiber icon visibly shrinking. RIGHT: bold red downward arrow with text MUSCLE ATROPHY ACCELERATES — EVEN WITH MORNING EXERCISE. Dark background, red warning theme, bold English labels, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That's a CRITICAL distinction. The morning workout doesn't cancel out eight hours in a chair.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Not even close. Your muscles interpret prolonged sitting as a signal: 'We're not needed anymore.'
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: The body adapts to what it does MOST... not what it does occasionally.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: So the fix isn't 'sit less' — it's BREAK the sitting. Stand up... move... even two minutes... every forty-five minutes.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: In Japan — this happens naturally. Smaller spaces, more walking, less dependence on cars.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Right. Americans have literally BUILT a lifestyle around not moving. And our muscles are paying for it.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Okay... habit number two?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Meal skipping. Specifically — skipping breakfast... or eating breakfast with ZERO protein.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: We touched on this with the protein timing conversation earlier.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: This is where it gets personal — because I did this for YEARS. Coffee and nothing else until noon.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: You?! A cardiologist... skipping breakfast?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: I was busy. Thought coffee was enough. Until you showed me the research on what that actually does to muscle after fifty.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: And you were genuinely surprised by those numbers.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Shocked. When you skip that morning protein window — your muscles go into BREAKDOWN mode, not maintenance.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Split-track process diagram showing morning protein impact. TOP track labeled WITH BREAKFAST PROTEIN showing: wake-up icon, then protein meal icon with green arrow, then healthy muscle fiber maintaining strength, label MUSCLE MAINTAINED. BOTTOM track labeled COFFEE ONLY showing: wake-up icon, then coffee cup icon with red arrow, then muscle fiber shrinking, label MUSCLE BREAKDOWN MODE — HOURS OF DAMAGE. Bold parallel comparison layout. Dark background, green versus red contrast, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: The overnight fast already depleted muscle glycogen — without protein... there's nothing to rebuild with.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: So every morning you skip protein — you're adding HOURS to the window where your muscles are actively breaking themselves down.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: And this compounds... over months and years. It's not one missed breakfast — it's hundreds.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Exactly. Now — the third habit. And this one... most people don't even think about.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: What is it?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Sleep disruption. Specifically — getting less than seven hours... or getting POOR quality sleep.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Sleep and muscle — people never connect those two things.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: But they SHOULD. Growth hormone — the signal that tells your muscles to repair and rebuild — is released almost entirely during deep sleep.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Process diagram showing sleep and muscle repair mechanism. Sleeping person icon at left with moon symbols. Arrow flowing right to brain icon releasing GROWTH HORMONE in green glow. Second arrow to muscle fiber icon rebuilding with green pulse, label MUSCLE REPAIR HAPPENS HERE. Below: two comparison boxes — GREEN box SEVEN PLUS HOURS DEEP SLEEP: FULL REPAIR versus RED box LESS THAN SIX HOURS: INCOMPLETE REPAIR with cracked muscle fiber. Dark background, blue night theme transitioning to green repair, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: So if you're not sleeping well... your muscles literally CANNOT recover from exercise.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Not fully. You're exercising AND losing ground at the same time.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That's why some people exercise faithfully... and STILL lose muscle. Their sleep is destroying every bit of progress.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: So let's bring this all together now.
data.broll_query: NANO_BANANO: Complete sarcopenia action framework summary infographic. TOP section with two green pillar icons: LEFT pillar PROTEIN: TWENTY-FIVE TO THIRTY-FIVE GRAMS, THREE MEALS A DAY RIGHT pillar RESISTANCE EXERCISE: TWO TO THREE TIMES PER WEEK. BOTTOM section with three red warning icons in a row: HABIT ONE: CHRONIC SITTING, HABIT TWO: SKIPPING BREAKFAST PROTEIN, HABIT THREE: POOR SLEEP. Bold white center text connecting both sections: FIX THESE — FIGHT SARCOPENIA. Dark background, green pillars versus red warnings, high contrast summary layout, 16:9 format. Create this in sketch style with hand-drawn linework and minimal color accents.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: If someone watching this could only do ONE thing starting tomorrow morning — what would you tell them?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: Add protein to breakfast. Twenty-five grams minimum. Two eggs... a scoop of Greek yogurt — something.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: That's it? Just breakfast?
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: That ONE change — done consistently — will have a bigger impact than anything else in the first two weeks. It breaks the overnight breakdown cycle.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Simple. Affordable. And you can start tomorrow morning.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: And of course — always talk to your doctor before making big changes to your diet or starting any new exercise program. Especially if you have existing conditions.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: This isn't about perfection. It's about STARTING. Small steps... consistent days. That is how you fight sarcopenia.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Michael
data.text: If this changed how you think about muscle loss — write in the comments. Have you noticed your strength declining? We want to hear from you.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3

data.speaker: Hiroshi
data.text: Take care of yourselves. And each other. Stay strong.
data.title: ep_sarcopenia_p3
